main_text:
Sister Concepts
5. Sister Concepts

The PJP ties itself to two essential concepts: publicity and
stability. A law that achieves stability and publicity may thereby
count as publicly justified. In other cases, theorists see reaching
publicity and stability as theoretical merits—considerations
that favor their approach to public justification over others. If a
version of the PJP conflicts with publicity, that could refute the
specification. Other factors can count against this specification of
the PJP. But publicity and stability are central to public
justification, so we explore connections.
